discussion.content:
Its regulatory requirement duh. Like in banks or goverment, they have a minimum retention of logs, not just technically, even physical documents, its just critical.

D only says technological limitation to store data. Lol hope you understand.

D makes the most sense... IT has the GREATEST impact if it is limited and the governing regulations change throwing the technical constraints out the window and the Org scrambling to make the required changes to comply......

I think D is the correct answer. My understanding of the question is that you already have the policies in place, but then what you stop an organization from satisfying those regulatory/policy requirements

I'm fairly confident that it's C. Look at this line from Cybersecurity Analyst Certification Bundle:

"A very straightforward and perhaps tempting approach would be to look at the lengthiest legal or regulatory retention requirement on your organization and then apply that timeframe to all your data retention. The problem with this is that it will probably make your retained data set orders of magnitude greater than it needs to be. Not only does this impose additional storage costs, but it also makes it more difficult to comply with electronic discovery (e-discovery) orders. A better approach is to find the specific data sets that have mandated retention requirements and handle those accordingly. Everything else has a retention period that minimally satisfies the business requirements."

Technical constraints are factored in creating a data retention policy, however the main factor is most definitely governing regulations.. if technical constraints only let you keep data for 6 months but regulations say you are required to keep for a year, you literally have no choice but to increase your orgs resources. https://thinksis.com/insights/what-to-consider-when-developing-a-data-retention-policy/
Agreed

Isn't this supposed to be letter C? A data retention policy is a recognized and proven protocol within an organization for retaining information for operational use while ensuring adherence to the laws and regulations concerning them.
why is it not regulations governing the data?

choices.C: The regulatory requirements concerning the data set
choices.D: The technical constraints of the technology used to store the data
choices.B: The level of sensitivity of the data established by the data owner
choices.A: The CIA classification matrix assigned to each piece of data

questions.question_text: Which of the following has the GREATEST impact to the data retention policies of an organization?

discussion.content: Quarterly based on PCI DSS, or as soon as any major change has been implemented.

questions.question_text: A company has decided to process credit card transactions directly. Which of the following would meet the requirements for scanning this type of data?

discussion.content: the best protection from bootkit level invection is TMP and removing local administrator which could prevent unauthorized command line usage
Users shouldn’t use administrator-level accounts for regular host operation. https://www.csoonline.com/article/3222066/how-to-detect-and-remove-a-rootkit-in-windows-10.html
How would removing local administrator privileges help in this situation?

choices.C: Install a secondary virus protection application.
choices.D: Enforce a system state recovery after each device reboot.
choices.B: Configure a BIOS-level password on the device.

questions.question_text: Which of the following countermeasures should the security administrator apply to MOST effectively mitigate Bootkit-level infections of the organization's workstation devices?

A new zero-day vulnerability was discovered within a basic screen capture app, which is used throughout the environment. Two days after discovering the vulnerability, the manufacturer of the software has not announced a remediation or if there will be a fix for this newly discovered vulnerability. The vulnerable application is not uniquely critical, but it is used occasionally by the management and executive management teams. The vulnerability allows remote code execution to gain privileged access to the system. Which of the following is the BEST course of action to mitigate this threat?

discussion.content: I disagree with D & C. I think this is B. This best defends against attack. C also works, but I feel like blocking the application is immediately necessary to protect the network. Remember, this is a non critical application, so they don’t need it.

comments.content: Think this is indeed B. It's a more substantial answer. Replace it with a non-vulnerable app would be a potential follow-up solution.
Since the app is occasionally used by the management and executive management teams, its best to find an alternative so C is the best option in this case.

discussion.content: The answer is correct, looking at the wording "used occasionally by the management" They can stop using the app till finding the right solution.

I agree with s3curity1 comment, and adding following point as well. "The vulnerability allows remote code execution to gain privileged access to the system". After this statement keeping the vulnerable Application by disabling the service also a Risk unless it is completely removed.

I think the word that makes the difference in this case is "mitigate" which makes B is the best answer. C would solve the problem completely but by forcing to find an alternative which might be the most welcomed solution.
C is a clear answer on this question
Definitely C. Where are the all the wrong answers coming from???

comments.content:
Yep, I agree C is a better choice. Communication won't ensure that this application will not be used, and there's also no guarantee that the vulnerability won't be exploited even if the application's process is not running.
Whereas letter C, will remove the entire risk of exploiting the vulnerability on that specific application, and will only affect a small number of users who occassionall use the application.

discussion.content: I want to go with C on this question

choices.A: Work with the manufacturer to determine the time frame for the fix.
choices.C: Remove the application and replace it with a similar non-vulnerable application.
choices.D: Communicate with the end users that the application should not be used until the manufacturer has resolved the vulnerability.
choices.B: Block the vulnerable application traffic at the firewall and disable the application services on each computer.

comments.content: We can only assume the forensics team has already used a write blocker to image the PC. I don't like the way CompTIA word their questions.

Very good explanation. I also initially thought that write blockers should replace the faraday cage. But in this situation, the task is only to deliver the PC, so yes, the security analyst should only ensure the PC has not been tampered with using A, B, and C.
But, isn't this wrong? They will lose all volatile information as they will be moving the PC from one place to another. They should have created a forensic image without moving it to the forensics lab.

discussion.content: I thought write blockers at first too. But the wording of the question says that the Security analyst is helping out. Hes not forensics so, he should not be tampering with the device at all. He's basically just delivering the PC. It should be A. Sealed with Tamper Proof seals. B. Placed in the Faraday Cage to block electromagnetic feilds, and C. Chain of custody needs to be filled out. Forensics will use the write blockers.
write blockers should be one of the answers. Not a faraday cage.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is assisting with a computer crime investigation and has been asked to secure a PC and deliver it to the forensic lab. Which of the following items would be MOST helpful to secure the PC? (Choose three.)
